sentence: The Delhi Sultanate was founded in <mark>1206</mark> by Central Asian Turks who were Indianized.

Later, after weakening and disintegration (after the Kamarupa-Palas), the Kamarupa tradition was somewhat extended until c. 1255 CE by the Lunar I (c. 1120–1185 CE) and Lunar II (c. 1155–<mark>1255</mark> CE) dynasties.

This period also covers the "Late Classical Age" of Hinduism, which began after the collapse of the Empire of Harsha in the 7th century, and ended in the 13th century with the rise of the Delhi Sultanate in Northern India; the beginning of Imperial Kannauj, leading to the Tripartite struggle; and the end of the Later Cholas with the death of Rajendra Chola III in <mark>1279</mark> in Southern India; however some aspects of the Classical period continued until the fall of the Vijayanagara Empire in the south around the 17th century.

The Vijayanagara Empire was established in <mark>1336</mark> by Harihara I and his brother Bukka Raya I of Sangama Dynasty, which originated as a political heir of the Hoysala Empire, Kakatiya Empire, and the Pandyan Empire.

In the south, the Bahmani Sultanate in the Deccan, born from a rebellion in <mark>1347</mark> against the Tughlaq dynasty, was the chief rival of Vijayanagara, and frequently created difficulties for them.
The Sultan's army was defeated on <mark>17 December 1398</mark>.
Deva Raya II succeeded to the throne in <mark>1424</mark> and was possibly the most capable of the Sangama Dynasty rulers.

Starting in <mark>1490</mark>, the Bahmani Sultanate's governors revolted, their independent states composing the five Deccan sultanates; Ahmadnagar declared independence, followed by Bijapur and Berar in the same year; Golkonda became independent in 1518 and Bidar in 1528.
In <mark>1498</mark>, a Portuguese fleet under Vasco da Gama discovered a new sea route from Europe to India, which paved the way for direct Indo-European commerce.
The Vedic Period of the Vedic people in northern India (<mark>1500</mark>–500 BCE) was marked by the composition of their extensive collections of hymns (Vedas).

In <mark>1526</mark>, Babur swept across the Khyber Pass and established the Mughal Empire, which at its zenith covered much of South Asia.

After Sher Shah's death, his son Islam Shah Suri and his Hindu general Hemu Vikramaditya established secular rule in North India from Delhi until 1556, when Akbar (r. 1556–1605), grandson of Babur, defeated Hemu in the Second Battle of Panipat on <mark>6 November 1556</mark> after winning Battle of Delhi.
It lasted until 1646, although its power declined after a major military defeat in <mark>1565</mark> by the combined armies of the Deccan sultanates.

It gained a foothold in India with the establishment of a factory in Masulipatnam on the Eastern coast of India in <mark>1611</mark> and a grant of rights by the Mughal emperor Jahangir to establish a factory in Surat in 1612.

On <mark>23 June 1757</mark>, Siraj ud-Daulah, the last independent Nawab of Bengal was betrayed in the Battle of Plassey by Mir Jafar.

In <mark>1765</mark> the system of Dual Government was established, in which the Nawabs ruled on behalf of the British and were mere puppets to the British.
The Anglo-Mysore Wars (<mark>1766</mark>–99) and the Anglo-Maratha Wars (1772–1818) left it in control of large areas of India south of the Sutlej River.
In <mark>1772</mark> the system was abolished and Bengal was brought under the direct control of the British.

The Maratha–Mysore War ended in <mark>April 1787</mark>, following the finalising of treaty of Gajendragad, in which Tipu Sultan was obligated to pay tribute to the Marathas.

British India officially declared war on Nazi Germany in <mark>September 1939</mark>.
The All India Azad Muslim Conference gathered in Delhi in <mark>April 1940</mark> to voice its support for an independent and united India.
Congress launched the Quit India Movement in <mark>August 1942</mark>, refusing to co-operate in any way with the government until independence was granted.

Japan gave nominal control of the islands to the Provisional Government of Free India on <mark>21 October 1943</mark>, and in the following March, the Indian National Army with the help of Japan crossed into India and advanced as far as Kohima in Nagaland.

This advance on the mainland of the Indian subcontinent reached its farthest point on Indian territory, retreating from the Battle of Kohima in June and from that of Imphal on <mark>3 July 1944</mark>.
Indians also aided in liberating British colonies such as Singapore and Hong Kong after the Japanese surrender in <mark>August 1945</mark>.

Late in <mark>1946</mark>, the Labour government decided to end British rule of India, and in early 1947 it announced its intention of transferring power no later than June 1948 and participating in the formation of an interim government.
In <mark>January 1946</mark>, several mutinies broke out in the armed services, starting with that of RAF servicemen frustrated with their slow repatriation.
The mutinies came to a head with mutiny of the Royal Indian Navy in Bombay in <mark>February 1946</mark>, followed by others in Calcutta, Madras, and Karachi.

Muslim League leader Muhammad Ali Jinnah proclaimed <mark>16 August 1946</mark> as Direct Action Day, with the stated goal of highlighting, peacefully, the demand for a Muslim homeland in British India, which resulted in the outbreak of the cycle of violence that would be later called the "Great Calcutta Killing of <mark>August 1946</mark>".

Most of the Rajput princes remained loyal to Britain in the Revolt of <mark>1857</mark>, and few political changes were made in Rajputana until Indian independence in <mark>1947</mark>.
There were officially 565 princely states in <mark>1947</mark>, but only 21 had actual state governments, and only three were large (Mysore, Hyderabad, and Kashmir).
They were absorbed into the independent nation in <mark>1947</mark>–48.
